facts.title: Strong Acid Properties
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is a highly corrosive strong acid with a pH less than 1.

facts.title: Industrial Uses
facts.description: It’s widely used in fertilizer production and battery manufacturing.

facts.title: King of Chemicals
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is often called the 'King of Chemicals' because of its vast industrial applications.

facts.title: Dehydrating Agent
facts.description: It can remove water from organic compounds, turning sugar into carbon instantly.

facts.title: Highly Exothermic Reaction
facts.description: Mixing sulfuric acid with water releases a large amount of heat, which can cause explosions if done improperly.

facts.title: Essential for Petroleum Refining
facts.description: Sulfuric acid plays a key role in refining crude oil into gasoline and other fuels.

facts.title: Used in Cleaning Metals
facts.description: It is used in metal processing to remove rust and oxidation from iron and steel.

facts.title: Vital for Paper Industry
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is used in the paper-making process to help break down wood fibers.

facts.title: Naturally Occurs in Acid Rain
facts.description: Small amounts of sulfuric acid are formed in the atmosphere due to sulfur dioxide emissions, contributing to acid rain.

facts.title: Battery Acid
facts.description: It is the key ingredient in lead-acid batteries used in cars and backup power systems.

faqs.question: What is sulfuric acid?
faqs.answer: Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) is a strong mineral acid used in various industries.

faqs.question: Is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes, it’s highly corrosive and requires careful handling.

faqs.question: What is sulfuric acid used for?
faqs.answer: It is used in battery manufacturing, fertilizer production, petroleum refining, and chemical processing.

faqs.question: Can sulfuric acid burn skin?
faqs.answer: Yes, it causes severe burns on contact with skin and requires immediate washing with water.

faqs.question: Is sulfuric acid found in nature?
faqs.answer: Yes, small amounts occur in acid rain and volcanic emissions.

faqs.question: How is sulfuric acid made?
faqs.answer: It is produced by oxidizing sulfur dioxide (SO₂) to sulfur trioxide (SO₃), then dissolving it in water.

faqs.question: Why is sulfuric acid called the 'King of Chemicals'?
faqs.answer: Because it is one of the most widely used industrial chemicals and is essential for many industries.

faqs.question: Can sulfuric acid dissolve metals?
faqs.answer: Yes, it reacts with many metals, releasing hydrogen gas and forming metal sulfates.

faqs.question: What happens if sulfuric acid is mixed with water?
faqs.answer: It releases a large amount of heat, which can cause splattering. Always add acid to water, not the other way around.

faqs.question: Is sulfuric acid used in medicine?
faqs.answer: Not directly, but it is used in the production of some pharmaceuticals and chemicals for medical use.
